bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests permission to study Kean's diary in depth. He poses a large number of questions concerning yellow fever work.

August 26, 1940
General J. R. Kean
2804 “N” St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean':
div1.p:
At last I have been able to write down in orderly sequence
the data I collected in Havana and since then. Permit me to send you a copy. I have
only had threefour or fourfive made, one to send to Moran, one to General Truby, one to Mrs.
Rojas, and one to Miss Agramonte, asking each to correct any mistakes that they may
find. I would certainly appreciate it if you will go over this and advise me of any
corrections you wish. Please remember that I do not want you to take the troulbe to
write your answers in long hand but if you will get the sergices of a secretary or
public stenographer and dictate to her whatever comes to your mind, in as much detail
as you can, I will be delighted to pay for her services. I am selfish about this as I
know that if you do it that way, I will get more information, so please do not hesitate
to do it.

The more I remember your diary, the more I am impressed by the
fact that quoted remarks from it would make one of the best possible introductions to
a paper, on the yellow fever work. I remember where day after day your diary spoke of
the new yellow fever cases. I wish I had had the opportunity of spending more time on
it, and of copying it more accurately. Would you be willing to do one or two more
things--either mail me your diary by registered, insured mail, or express, so that I
might spend several days on it, copy out of it only that which is sufficiently impersonal
and yet useful to the story, submit to you what I have copied for your approval, when I
return the diary; or would you prefer, that is if you are willing, to dictate to the
secretary under the respective dates given in your diary, everything pertaining to your
experience with yellow fever, including the dates and statements you made about the new
cases coming down day after day.

May I ask you certain specific questions which concern the numbered
paragraphs in my memorandum?

Paragraph 6: Do you know when the tent Camp Columbia was erected,
and replaced by the wooden Columbia Barracks? What was Camp Columbia used for before
hand? Can you tell me when Columbia Barracks was torn down in favor of the Military City?

Par. 8: What was the relationship and rank of Doctor Cooke, Captain
Godfrey, and Major Michie, at Pinar? When was the exact date when Reed joined Agramonte
at Pinar? Do you have any idea where I can obtain photographs of the post hospital at
Columbia Barracks, in particular the officers' quarters there? The Army Museum has none.

Par. 10: Do you know exactly when in August, 1900, the members of
the board called on Finlay for his larvae? I understand it was the first week. Do you
know who visited Finlay? with Reed?

Par. 11: Do you know on what date of the first week of August
that Reed left Havana, and on what boat?

Par. 12: Between August 11 and 25, 1900, Lazear applied the
infected mosquitos to 9 U.S. soldiers, among the Lazear himself, Carroll, and Pinto.
The other 6 remained unidentified. Do you have any idea who they were?

Par. 13: I believe I told you Kissinger's version of the inoculation
of Dean. He told me that Dean, having scoffed at the yellow fever work, had the habit of
taking an after lunch nap in the hospital where he was a patient. Carroll, having come
down with yellow fever that morning, Lazear and Agramonte decided to pick a volunteer at
once. Lazear found Dean asleep, and according to Kissinger, put the mosquito on him while
he was asleep. Later, when Dean heard why he had gotten yellow fever, presumably he was
very angry at first, later enjoyed the experience of being a hero. This version differs
entirely with Agramonte's version (see Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1915). Agramonte says
Dean was passing the hospital and Lazear asked him if he would volunteer, to which Dean
jokingly replied, “Yes.” Did you ever hear the Kissinger version when you were in Cuba?
What do you think of it? Moran knew nothing of it.

Par. 14: Do you know whether Lazear and Carroll made a formal
pact not to be infected, and was it authorized by Reed? Where did Carroll do his con-
valescing? Was he cared for in the post hospital at Columbia Barracks during his illness?

Par. 15 and 16: I am particularly anxious to have any information
which you would give me as to the real story of Lazear's illness, and I am glad you agree
with me that it is time to give Dr. Lazear this belated recognition. I am sure that if I
have your approval and that of Miss Agramonte, I can also get that of Moran and Gen. Truby
to mention this version. I will so appreciate as detailed a statement as you can give me.

Par. 16: Did Dr. Lazear die in the post hospital at Columbia
Barracks? Where was he buried and when and where was the body re-interred? Where is he
now buried?

Par. 17: Can you give me any information on the correspondence between
Reed in Washington, and Carroll of Agramonte in Havana regarding Lazear's death? My
statement in this paragraph “much to the later annoyance of Reed” was inserted on the
basis of something you told me, but I forgot to find out how and when this annoyance was
expressed.

Par. 19: You have been entirely too modest. General Truby tells
me that you and Gen. Wood did more to help Reed than anybody else. Presuming that you
do not wish to write on your help to Reed in the first person, I would appreciate it
greatly if you would dictate as much as you can as just what your contribution to Reed
was, and I shall be delighted to put this into my story. You will, of course, and others
concerned, have a chance to see my story for your final corrections long before its pub-
lication. In particular, can you give me more details on your conversation with Reed on
your way to see Gen. Wood, and of the conference with Wood? Reed left Havana to go to
Washington “about the middle of October, 1900” to tell the surgeon general about his plans
and to give his preliminary report before the American Public Health Association in
Indianapolis. Do you know exactly what this date was?

Par. 21: Reed returned to Havana “ early in November, 1900”. Do
you know on what date?

Par. 22: Just who were the eleven soldiers who went into residence
at Camp Lazear on Nov. 20, 1900? Who were the personnel of the camp? The official
records do not make this clear. Do you personally know anything about the circumstances
of the volunteering of Moran and Kissinger? Did Reed tell you anything about it? Did
they go to Reed together or separately? How was the call for volunteers put out? by
Reed or by Dr. Ames, and in what form, by written notice or by word of mouth?

Par. 23: What was the exact method by which Kissinger, Moran,
Benigno and Presedo were bitten by mosquitos between Nov. 20 and 30, 1900? Where at
Camp Lazear did the inoculations take place, in Reed's office tent, or in the tent of
the volunteers themselves? Who officiated and carried out these inoculations. Did
Reed always do this? When was the building of the Infected Clothing Building begun?
It was ready for occupancy Nov. 20.

Par. 27: When was the Infected Mosquito Building begun? It was
ready for occupancy, Dec. 21. Who were the two volunteers who slept 18 nights in the
mosquito-free side of the Infected Mosquito Building between Dec. 21, 1900 and Jan. 8, 1901

Par. 29: Do you know anything about the disbanding of Camp Lazear,
and what happened to the wooden buildings? Did you yourself ever visit Camp Lazear?
Could you see any rather hilly country from the Camp, and do you remember the relation
of the Camp to the Rojas farmhouse, its distance and direction? When did Carroll leave
Cuba for the U.S.? Was it in Feb. 1900 or later?

Par. 49: I am anxious to have your reaction to this paragraph.
Pars. 101

Pars. 101-104: I am also anxious to have your reactions to these
paragraphs.

Par. 109: What was the relation of Quemados to Marianao--separate
towns or what?

Par. 112: You remember Reed spoke of the people who got sick in
#102 Real St. and in #20 Gen. Lee Street. Do you know who they were? I thought you
said that some of your friends lived in one of those houses.
Par. 115 and 116: I am anxious to have your opinion of this.
Par. 118 and 119: Please give me your opinion of these.
Par. 122: Please check this paragraph.

Par. 123: Is Major Michie alive? Would he have any information
regarding the yellow fever work?
Pars. 125-126: Please check.

Is Dr. Ames living? Reed's letter to Carroll, Feb. 26, 1900 says
Ames had a map of the Quemados epidemic. I would certainly like to see a map of Quemados
of 1900. Could you send me a copy of the circular you issued October 15, 1900 and of your
Gen. Order, No. 6, issued Dec. 21, 1900? Do you have many letters from Walter Reed? If
there are not too many, would you let the stenographer copy them, the direct quotations fr
letters of Survivors will do much to increase the interest of any story written on this
work.

I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your magnificent help in this
matter, and I only hope that I can do justice to those concerned.
